page.title: 04FORESTRY COMMISSION (cont'd)
page.content: Trees are felled by chainsaw and, after snedding, the trees are taken to the forest's edge. When new trees are planted they are protected by fibreglass tubes to prevent them being nibbled by rabbits, sheep and deer; parts of the forest are also fenced for this reason. Some softwood is sold for pit-props locally but most goes for re-processing in the locality as 'artificial' compressed board. More valuable timber (sawlogs) is sold to the highest bidder in parcels as areas are felled. Specialist products (veneers) are sold after negotiation. Small timber left after felling is sold in parcels to local people for firewood. Bark peelings from oak trees are also sold for use in the tanning process as are other peelings which make good ground covering for riding stables.
